turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 47, Sam Ginsberg, Appellant, versus New York.
Mr. Redfield.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, members of the Court.

This is an appeal from the judgment of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court of the State of New York which affirmed a conviction of the appellant for having violated Section 484-h of the Penal Law of the State of New York.

Since the Highest Court of the State of New York, the Court of Appeals did not take this case for review, the Appellate Term as the Court in which -- it was a final court in which a judgment could be had.
And this judgment raises several important and noble questions.

And the first one is, was there on its face and in its operation, is Section 484-h of the Penal Law repugnant to the constitution, the amendment -- First Amendment and the Fourteenth Amendment because it acts as a restraint upon expression.
The second question is, is the statute vague and overbroad by its terms and its standards if it has meaningful standards?
And third, is this publication or before publications involved within the scope of the statute in other words, was the Act validly applied to this particular plaint -- appellant.
I should say at the outset Your Honors --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether it was in this -- within the scope of the statute just that question isolate it is a matter of state law, isn't it?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, I mean constitutionally.
In other words of these -- is this particular magazine for example --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Within the scope of the statute that's a matter of state law, New York law.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Was in the scope but as applied, as the statute has been applied and construed with respect to this particular publication can you condemn this appellant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, does the constitution permits you to do what the state did with respect to that publication regardless of what the statute says, that's our question as to --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, that's in it.

I should say at the outset Your Honors that if this weren't a criminal conviction and I had a choice in the matter I would have not -- confining the issue solely to the first question because I think the issue was right.
And not only is it right but I think it is imperative that a decision be reached on that point even if the appellant can be victorious on any of the other points.
I think Your Honors, should at this time undertake the task of putting – address this question which has caused so many uncertainties and so much debate.

And the question comes down to this, whether the power of the state maybe exercised to punish a person who sells certain publications enumerated in the statute to persons based on the age of the reader or the purchaser.
And I say too that the basic question -- that basic question falls unto two categories.

The first, as a matter of principle, is it repugnant to the constitution and secondly, that by its operation in effect as a pragmatic question, does it intimidate the vendor and publisher of books to the point where it become censorship?
In other words, the second question to be clear is similar to the question that was raised and decided in Smith against California.

Smith against California you recall was a purely practical decision because the Court found that under the circumstances of the operation of the statute intimidation resulted was its consequent censorship.

Now, the court below and -- meaning the Appellate Term in writing for affirmance wrote nothing and the Court of Appeals also stated nothing but I suspect from the argument that went on that it's determination came about because of the case of the Bookcase against Broderick which was decided about a year ago in the Court of Appeals of the State of New York in which I brought to this Court.

The Bookcase decision rested on a dictum in the Jacobellis case and also rested on the dissenting language in People against Bookcase in which case, a prior law had been rendered unconstitutional by the Highest Court of New York.
So at this point, I cannot give you the ultimate construction of the statute as rendered in this case but can only refer you to what was said in Bookcase against Broderick.
My appellant who received the suspended sentence is not a flamboyant vendor nor a self-seeking or say like charging along in the rights of free speech.
He is just the poor, simple, humble owner of a candy store or stationary store or a newspaper (Inaudible) that sort of a place that is so common throughout this country.
He has this little store which of size 70 by -- seven by 30 feet in the little village of Bellmore, Long Island, New York.
And he works from morning to late at night with his wife to eat out in existence.
And it's so much though, that he had to shut the store for about three days during the pendency of the trial under this case.
And as I said, he sells almost everything that that type of a store sells and as part of it, he carries about 200 titles of magazines.
He has no choice in these titles, they are sent to him automatically by the jobbers.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You mean there are tie-in kinds of (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: They're sort of tie-in and the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And if he wants Time (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, he doesn't write --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Those things (Voice Overlap)--

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- he has to takeover rest?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: He has to take that or I'll -- let's put it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that all in the record?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: That's in the record but not as a tie-in and not -- is not developed to that extent but it is developed to the extent what -- which we properly know in the field and that is that he doesn't order these magazines, they just come to him from the distributor.

Now, the charge against him was on October 18th, 1965 he sold two magazines, one called Mr. Annual and the other is Sarah this thing and if Your Honors recall just a few months ago as I can recall, you had this particular title before you in the case of Gent versus Arkansas which I argued here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the title?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Sarah is in the name of the magazine.
It's not the same issue as involved in Gent but it's of similar publication, it's a girly type of magazine that in nearly date we used to call them Police Gazette Magazines.
And now they call it “Girly” and then there was another charge against him.
Then on October 26, 1965, he sold magazine called “Man to Man” an escapade to a similar type of magazines.
And it should be observed, why -- of course he sold them to this boy of 16 years of age.
It should be observed that the charge here is only that these pictures contain nudes and I should -- that the magazines contained pictures that were nudes and that these were harmful to minors.
That's all the charge is and I emphasize it because you will see in a few minutes that the judge made findings which extended beyond that charge.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are you asking us to review the findings?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: No, I'm not asking to review it but you could only take on the findings upon which he was charged, Cole against Arkansas situation, he was only charged with a certain crime.
It can only be found under that charge.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, specifically, are you complaining about the finding that the written material apart from the photographs?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, that's right and --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And you say that that --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: That should be disregarded because I don't think its part of the charge.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: At the time of the trial, the defendant challenged the constitutionality of the statute on its face and he was overruled and was convicted, the Appellate Terms they said before affirmed and the Court of Appeals refused to review.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you repeat why Mr. Redfield, repeat why we shouldn't take in a consideration that reading matter in the magazine as well as the pictures?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Because he wasn't charged with the reading matter, he was charged merely --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What was the charge?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: The charge --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You said --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: The charge was that he -- that these magazines contained nude pictures, that's all.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.
You'll find the charge on page 2 and 4 in the record.
But I don't want to dwell on that too much although I bring it to your attention.
I think there are more important issues in this case.
Yes, you -- the charges on page 2 to 4 of the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, of course that's a very important issue if he was charged in one thing and convicted (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, that's a -- but I say its subsidiary to my main contention in this case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What do you mean, you're waiving it?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: No, I'm not waiving it.
Since as I've said before he was convicted of a crime, I can't waive it.
I'd rely upon it as the last straw.

The judge after the trial made the following finding that the boy was 16 years of age and that the defendant knew or had reason to know that he was under 17 years of age and all the magazines in question contained pictures of nudes.

And then he made a charge -- finding that the magazine Escapade and Mr. Annual contain variable descriptions and narrative accounts of sexual excitement and sexual conduct, so you see, there alone, it goes beyond the charge.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, let me get this, this is at page 248, isn't it?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: No, on page -- I'm reading from page 5 -- yes, in the record, its on page --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm looking at the Court's finding.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In which he finds that people who are proven beyond a reasonable doubt before he was 16, defendant who had reason to know that it was that, and that People's Exhibit two, three, four and five, now those are the four magazines, are they?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Contained pictures and photographs depicting female nudities as to find by the Courts as sexual?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And this has last further.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That People's Exhibit five and People's Exhibit three contained a verbal descriptions and narrative accounts of sexual excitement and sexual conduct?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, that's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that's what you say is beyond the charge --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Scope of the charge --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- and that's the Cole-Arkansas point, is it?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, but as I say I'm not pressing that as the ultimate decision in this case --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You're not pressing it.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: No, I mean --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't quite understand it.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: I mean my emphasis here is for a decision --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean there's something else that's more important?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, I do.
I do think --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You want us to declare the statute unconstitutional, that's what you want?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Even if you can win by -- on the Cole-Arkansas (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Right sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Why do you do that Mr. Redfield?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, I'm not trying to make it harder for --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You've argued -- the last time you were here, you tried that too.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, I try also nothing, sometimes I succeed, in other times not.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You put great stress upon this man being very a poor man, this old man, so were the -- I would think it could be -- interested in winning your case anyway you could win it for him.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: And -- well, I also place that emphasis I should say because many people confused as Ginsberg was another Ginsberg that was here before and I think that distinction is very clear in this case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What was the sentence in this case?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: He got to suspended sentence.
The judge thought so highly of him that the man in the community was worthy of his indulgence and he suspended the sentence.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: For how long?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: He didn't mention, he just said suspended sentence and that was it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He doesn't impose a sentence and then suspend it?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, what was the sentence that he suspended?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: He didn't impose any sentence.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, then you --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: He just said, suspended sentence.
It's very common practice in New York to state that.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Do you challenge that practice?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That was successfully challenged here not long ago.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: I remember that but I haven't -- you know I should men -- it should be pointed out too that this statute is directed at those who sell the magazines for a monetary consideration.
In other words, if it were given away, the person couldn't be guilty of the crime but if he got money for it, it made a big difference.

And the reason I emphasize this is so that you could see that there is something wrong with the statute right off because if the purpose of the statute is to restrict the promiscuous circulation of this type of magazine to those under 17 they certainly haven't attained that even in the text because it can be distributed to those who will not pay a monetary consideration.
In other words, if one of Tom Sawyer's crowd came along and offered a bookseller an apple, that would be alright?
But if he got ten cents for it, he can go to jail for a year.

Now, of course we all would like to have the best of literature for the children and I would say also for adults and perhaps if I were an emperor, I would say there are certain 25 books that everybody can't -- may read and that would be it but since I'm not an emperor and I do not care to tell anybody what they may read, I have serious doubt as to whether or not there was great wisdom in this law.

And also point out the fact that several of the amicus in this case as well as the Columbia law review had found some solace in the recent Gold case in which children's right to read should be considered and protected because children wished to be free of the orthodoxy of adults.
But -- and this relates too to the observation made earlier today that children do not have freedom of speech as much as adult.
Therefore, they're not protected by the constitution.

I seriously doubt if the basis for the protection of the constitution rest on the freedom of choice of children that is that the assumption made by Mr. Justice Stewart that because adults have a greater freedom of choice therefore the children have to be protected.
Well, I'm not so sure that adults have that free to choice.
My opinion, people are great imitators, adult also sheep like everybody else and the tendency is to follow the leader.

I think the gist of the First Amendment is not that there is a freedom of choice in the (Inaudible) as there is a freedom of expression and the speaker was a writer or the publisher, that's what we're protecting.
There's nothing in the constitution that speaks of the audience.
It's good to turn in this argument to the beginning of the things and I start with Roth.
Roth --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Before you do that I'm not sure I understand what you last said.
You mean the First Amendment does not protect anybody except the speaker?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And that you can make any sort of -- well, how do you fit that with your theory in this case that -- then it would follow wouldn't it that you can assess the scope of the police power of the state without reference to the First Amendment insofar as the issue relates to who may buy these magazines, they maybe so-called?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Oh, I wasn't approving any -- I wasn't approving any such doctrine that the --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I'm not asking you what you're approving.
I'm asking you what you're understanding is, which you -- as you said that the --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: The First Amendment does direct, (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- the First Amendment does not protect the -- a right to hear, a right to read --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- did you say that?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: I said that the First Amendment is directed to the rights of the speaker not so much as to the right of the individual or the regulation of the receiver of the information.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well then where does that lead you in this case then the police power of the state can operate within reasonable limits but without any special reference to the First Amendment.
I'm trying to understand you --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, here -- what my protection is here is the protection of the vendor which is the same as the First Amendment speech.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: What you're saying then is that the protective interest, your submission is that the constitution protects not the child's right to read but the vendor's right to sell and the author's derivative right to turn out this store?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.
Well --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And so you relinquish any argument based upon the right of children or of adults for that not to read?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Right.

Well, I meant that in this respect, I said that there were others who went further than I did in this case, the amicus and the (Inaudible) law review who say that the Gold case protects the right of the reader or the child in this case but I wasn't pressing that issue, I on other hand was protecting the right of the vendor or the expresser of any idea.
So, I'd say this that the burden of proof as we know are the restraint on speech is of really a very heavy one and the burden is that of the state who would like to -- who would restrain this right.
But in anticipation -- in other words, I could say let's wait in here from the state and see what they have to say on their side.
But in anticipation of that, I would like to raise these questions, where is this authority derived?

The constitution says, there shall be no abridgement to speech and then Roth, you said, “Well, so far as obscenity is concerned there has been a history although some have debated that history to respect you Justice Brennan”.
And the -- so the question comes up, “Where in the constitution can you justify a restraint based upon the age of the reader?”
And I for myself cannot find such authority.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let us suppose this is based on the premise that minors or at least -- they're only 16 or 18 have less IQ than those of others?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, so I thought it's above that age.
Yes Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So, really what they're talking about here and all of these I presume is the kind to protect people with low IQs?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

And how you're going to determine those IQs to begin with and how about those who are above the age, about 50-year-olds who don't have the IQ and how about those who've set -- 16 years who have the IQs?
Who is going to determine that and why should anybody be subjected to this?
And specially --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I presume if you can -- had the right to read it on the age, you can decide upon the IQs, isn't that constitutionally?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, whether -- if that was so, I don't know what we do about it -- I mean I don't know how we could administer such a law or how to or better yet how one could sell books on -- or magazines under that type of the law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I presume most everyone known people of 16 who had far more IQ or whatever that is, a man of 50.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Some men of 50?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: That's what I've argued here.
And the -- and oh, -- and you could immediately see the Pandora's Box that is being opened here and when you realize that the objectives of these law can never really be attained.
I argued in my brief that these objectives are not attained because the younger children could get them from elders, they can always find them around.
Secondly, what is even worst in order to prosecute anybody you'd have to do what you did in this case and that is involved the youngsters in the criminal court.
The youngster in this case was acted as a decoy in the case that was specially framed for the purposes of enforcing this law.

And of all the most remarkable things that I know of that an amicus brief in this case in opposition to my position the citizens with decent literature took the very same position that this law cannot be enforced and its worst than if there were no such law because the debasement of the child is a factor that is worst than the literature that they could read.
I have a great deal more to argue but my time is up Your Honor.
I'll have to rely upon my brief.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you one -- returning to your first argument, what page did you say it to be found on that the judge can rely not merely on the pictures of nudity but on the literature that was in the --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: 248 of the record.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: 248, the last paragraph from the button of that page.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Alright.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Cahn.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What about this Cole and Arkansas point?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Which is that the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: The -- that he was convicted on something which he wasn't charged?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Oh, I don't believe that's quite sir correct because --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's important, I mean --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If that were so, this couldn't stand I take it, could it?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Oh, I would agree Mr. Justice Brennan that the information specifically charges in --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where is the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: -- in the second count.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Page 4?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Three?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Page 4?
What language charges the written material?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The language here suggests harmful to minor in the -- and which taken as a whole is harmful to minors.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: To minors?
And now, that incorporates the --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- the written as well as the --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The written as well as the pictorial part (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, why do you say that?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Because the entire statute gives reference Mr. Justice Brennan in its description of what is the obscene.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's the statute but the charge doesn't?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The charge mentions in the second count.

The defendant did violate the provisions of the said Section 484-h subdivision 2(b) of the Penal Law and that the defendant knowingly -- did knowingly sell to a minor a magazine which and taken as a whole is harmful to minors and I submit Your Honors that this applies to the written as well as to the pictorial part of the magazine.

I believe that the major issue on this appeal is whether a state may consistent with the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment enact the law founded upon the variable obscenity concept prohibiting the commercial distribution to children under 17 years of age of materials obscene as to such children although not necessarily obscene as to adults.
And whether the statute in question Section 484-h of the Penal Law of the State of New York is a valid children's obscenity law whether its phraseology is sufficiently definite.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Cahn.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How is it that New York has 17 and Dallas has 16?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: This is a matter for the legislature Mr. Justice Marshall --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Out of the clear blue?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Out of the clear blue?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, the legislature found it in its wisdom that the obscenity statute in reference to 484-h should apply to those under 17 and perhaps for different reasons in the State of Texas found that it should apply to those under 16 for the reason that -- the states have considerate 21 to be the age for qualified voting rather than 15, 16, 17 or 18.

I have no definite reason to give you as to why the state legislature saw fit to limit its exercise over children to the age of 17 rather than 16 or to 18 or to 19 or to any other age for that matter.

And if I may continue, the question is whether or not the statute's phraseology is sufficiently definite to satisfy the minimum requirements of due process as they relate to obscenity and whether its scienter clause is objectionable or exerting an undue restraint on commercial distribution to adults of materials within the prohibition of 484-h.
484-h, a violation of which was punishable as a misdemeanor is a children's obscenity law validly based on the variable obscenity concept approved by this Court in Mishkin against New York.

It was characterized as a children's obscenity law by New York's Highest Court, the Court of Appeals in the Bookcase Incorporated against Broderick case and this Court of course held in Mishkin that it will accept such a characterization.

I submit that the Court of Appeals characterization is correct since the statute's definition of harmful to minors includes the elements of this Court's definition of obscenity that is predominant, appeal to prurient interest, patent, offensiveness and absence of social importance with slight adjustments of wording necessary to relate and confined its prohibiting reach to children.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. Cahn, that being the -- those being terms of the statute?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I've just looked at these magazines.

I think you'd agree limiting this now to the pictures for the moment that magazines precisely like this in the context of obscenity determinations of distribution to adults have been held by this Court in number of cases now to be not obscene.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That is -- there's no question about it.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So, you got to say that although in their distribution to adults they are not obscene.
Nevertheless, we should fashion a principle that in their distribution to children under 17 they are obscene, is that it?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Even though it does not -- it is not obscene as to adults and adults in this particular statute are not bound by the rigid concepts established by the statute.

The Court of Appeals decided in the Broderick case rightly it is submitted that children were a recipient group within the Mishkin doctrine because they are the group to whom the objectionable material is directed or from whom it's quarantined.
The Court may judicially notice I submit that these materials including girly magazines are directed to children.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, why do you say that?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Because experience is thought as --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I know.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: -- Mr. Justice Fortas that the teenager is the greatest market for these girly magazines.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Is that in the record?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: It is submitted and suggested by the appellee's brief.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, it's not.
Is there anything in the record because that's surprising to me?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No, there is none sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: There is none.
I have limited experience but I know it would not take judicial notice of that fact, is that what you're suggesting?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, I am suggesting that because of my own experience Your Honor I have found that --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, these stories -- is the written material in here to -- on the level of what you commonly think of as boys, of course when I was younger, it was the (Inaudible) boys and things like that?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Time has changed since then --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Times had changed.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: -- Mr. Justice Fortas.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: But is that so as a written material of the -- what is specifically and specially a youthful kind?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The magazines which we refer, the magazines in question are written and insofar as my own personal opinion is concerned with a direction toward the teenage market and not very bright teenagers at that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And what?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: And not very bright teenagers at that.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, I -- to me this is an important point and -- but I don't know that the -- I would -- the liberty to take your judgment for the -- and the absence of anything in the record.

That is, I know of nothing so far as I have gone through the record here that would indicate that these magazines were specially prepared or specially directed for the -- that segment of the population which is included in the statute?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I might agree Mr. Justice Fortas but as I said it has appeared from the experience which I have had with dealers --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, you might agree or you might not but there's nothing in the record.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Nothing in the record.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: There's no question about that.
Now, I think that the Mishkin case holds that it will accept the characterization as placed upon the statute by the Court of Appeals.
And I have already mentioned the basis of the Court of Appeals characterization.
In the Mishkin and Ginzburg cases, I think that very frankly that the Court has noticed the prurient interest of these so-called girly magazines.
And in Mishkin, no psychiatric testimony or the light was presented to show that the material in question appealed to the prurient interest of pseudo masochist.

However, 484-h could've exercised its regulatory effect constitutionally even if it were not an obscenity law and thus the question of whether the state's proof in this case satisfy the obscenity criteria of 484-h is not a federal question eligible for decision by this Court.
Since the people's proof shows beyond a reasonable doubt sailed with the requisite scienter of nude photo magazine, nude photo magazines to a 16-year-old boy.

It has proved all that need to be proved to justify criminal punishment on constitutional grounds where the attribute of sovereignty on which the prosecution and statute is founded is the state's power as parens patriae for the benefit of children.

Since 484-h is an obscenity law, I don't believe the appellant can raise the First Amendment objections through it since under this Court's holding in the Roth against the United States case, obscenity is not protected -- is not protected expression.
The scienter provision knowingly is not invalid on its face because it will not restrict by indirect effect the flow of protected material to adults within the rationale of Smith against California.
This is so because most adults are patently over the age limit set out in 484-h under 17 years of age.
Thus dealers will not withhold sale to adults and will not fail to make a sale where the adult is a customer.
Moreover, the law provides for the defensive honest mistake as to age.

It follows that the deal who has made inquiry as to age and receive reassurance will rot -- will rely on the honest mistake provision and will not hesitate to sell to an adult at all even if the dealer has not examined the working question.

In the few situations where age is in doubt, the buyer to whom allegedly the dealer might be hesitant to sell in the absence of an honest mistake provision as to age will usually not be an adult but instead will be a youngster.

Indeed, most youngsters in this marginal age group are so young that they have been included in 4 -- that they could've have been included in 484-h's prohibition without giving constitutional offense.

Thus, indirect restriction on distribution to them does not raise federal questions since they could be denied access by direct prohibition, it's constitutionally indifferent whether the state has instead contrived this accepts -- acceptable denial of access by indirect means.
There is nothing constitutionally objectionable in placing the burden of judgment on the book dealer and to require him to determine if the material sold by him comes within the prohibited class.

In Mishkin, this Court approved the New York statute namely Section 118 -- 44 of Penal Law the old Section 1141, excuse me, which it viewed as placing the same burden of judgment on book dealers as on publishers.
Appellants claimed in this regard a vagueness argument in disguise.

But this Court in effect has held that the definitions of obscenity in Roth against United States, Manual Enterprises against Day, Jacobellis against Ohio and the Mishkin, Ginzburg and Fanny Hill cases are adequate.
It follows that the definitions in 484-h give sufficiently definite noticed of what materials are within its prohibition and do not place an excessive burden on the deal.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I don't understand you sir because you are -- I thought you agreed on response to the questions by Mr. Justice Brennan that these magazines would not be held obscene and therefore outside of the First Amendment protections in the case of an adults.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So what comfort do you get out of Roth and all the rest of them?
You've got to go beyond that, don't you, to take care of this particular case and say that two things are outside of the protection of the First Amendment.
Number one, the Roth type of thing as embellished by subsequent cases and number two, something that is less than Roth in the case of children, don't you have to take that position?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No, I -- Mr. Justice Fortas, I agree that these magazines if sold to adults would not constitute a violation of any obscenity statute.

However, taking these magazines insofar as children are concerned I submit that they are obscene -- that they have been held obscene by our State's Highest Court in accordance with definitions set forth in Roth and the other cases with changes in phraseology limiting its application to children.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And your state's -- from your state courts might have held that over and over again.But by on the basis of a colloquy between you and Mr. Justice Brennan, this Court would have to say that these particular magazines here are within the protection of the First Amendment if you relied only on Roth and our decisions today.
Now what you're asking us to do and I perhaps you have to ask us to do is to come out with another category.
Category restricted to statutes dealing with children.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, this is the --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: (Inaudible) in the statute, I certainly (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: -- variable concept doctrine, is it not --

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: -- would be straightened out on it.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I believe that this is the variable concept doctrine Mr. Justice Fortas.
I maybe mistaken but I believe this concept definitely applies in this particular situation.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Now, what is the -- what would you add to the Roth definition or subtract on the Roth definition in the case of children or why do you say that these magazines although by hypothesis would not be held obscene in the case of adults should be held to be within the First Amendment -- it should be held outside of the First Amendment protection in the case of children?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Because taken as a whole these magazines are harmful to minors as our statute specifically states.
That the magazines in question, these magazines although not obscene to -- insofar as adults are concern when taken into consideration in the juvenile area are harmful to minors.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And what -- and we have to sustain that as being sufficiently precise and not too broad or too vague for First Amendment purposes?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes, because harmful -- the terms in the statute are very explicitly explained each and every term used, nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, sadomasochistic abuse, harmful to minors and prurient interest and so forth.
Each and every item to which the statute refers is clearly defined by the statute.
And the changes to which I refer making the overall magazine harmful to minors is that which I asked to this Court to take in to consideration to accept.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you if your court has ever sustained this particular charge made in count two, to the extent of saying that it charged anything more than the fact that these were bad because they add pictures of nude persons?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, I cannot honestly answer the question, I don't know.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- as I read it, I read a different -- draw a different inference to yours.
It seems to me, that what they are saying that taken as a whole these pictures of nude persons are harmful to minors.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The magazine taken as a whole.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I don't find that.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Oh, I see sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I haven't been able to find (Inaudible), it seems to me like it means the other.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I would have to (Voice Overlap) this Court --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Whatever construed it the other way.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Oh, I gather that under this -- as I read the statute, nudity alone doesn't -- isn't -- is not proscribed.
I gather that its only nudity which is harmful to minors --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: True.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- and nudity which is harmful to minors has to be patently offensive --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Patently offensive --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material for minors.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That is correct and --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And is that really without redeeming social importance for minors.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That is correct sir.
And so, under this particular statute great works of art would not be involved.
The nudity in the magazine must appeal to prurient interest must be without social importance.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I take it though the -- any picture -- any nude picture in a magazine would be bad under the statute?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No sir, not any nude picture, the -- these magazines which contained pictures of nudes we contend that we proved were directed to the prurient interest where without social value were provocative, were sexual -- were for the purpose of sexually stimulated.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you got one in particular you could show us?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'd looked at all of them.
You got in one page you could suggest that that nude is different from the other nude?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I don't have the magazine with me at this time Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Redfield, I had one there, some I guess, over there.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The one in question?
I submit --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Go ahead, do you have one?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I submit that all of these pictures as they are, are for the purpose of sexual stimulation rather than for purposes of displaying great works of art --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then you say all nudes?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: All of these nudes in their positions, in their --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, that --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: -- provocative positions --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I don't see any difference from those nudes and all other nudes we've had come in through here?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Insofar as children are concerned, Mr. Justice Marshall?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We've been looking at them, to all of them, for children.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, this is why --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I'm just trying to say, aren't you actually saying that nude in and of itself is bad --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's what --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: -- for children?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's really -- I really, it's a -- I wonder if a statute wouldn't reach all nude -- any kind of a nude in that magazine?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I respectfully must disagree with the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, let me ask you.
What about the nudist magazines?
Which you've been held not obscene for adults, how do you think they would fair under --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Mr. Justice White I have enough of a problem to cope with that which I have rather than to become a profit and I don't know.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Okay fine, thank You.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: This is really up to the Court's to decide.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I must say Mr. Cahn, I don't know why you say that any picture in light of two ways instantly this is -- this prosecutions under the 65 statute of course not under the amended 67 statute.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That's correct sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, they -- as I read at page 29 I'm looking at Mr. Redfield's brief.

The statute, unlawful for any person knowingly to sell or loan for monetary consideration of a minor any picture; skip the rest of it; or any photograph which depicts nudity and which is harmful to minors.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: And the harmful to minors is very vividly described in subdivision (f).

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
It has to have all of the Roth elements.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That's correct sir.
But --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Any single picture, it would seem to me looking at A, that satisfied that description and this magazine even if none of the others did would support a prosecution under A, wouldn't it?
As for a single picture --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes.
If it violated the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, if it was harmful to minors with --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I would say so.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, so that the (Inaudible) taken as a whole is meaningless, isn't it?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, that's in subdivision (a).

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but this gets me, that's why I'm trouble by the Cole and Arkansas point.
I must say I have difficulty reading count two as drawing in what apparently the trial judge relied on, namely the written materials.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Oh, I don't think he relied on that.
I think he added that insofar as his judgment was concerned and I think he had absolutely every right to do so under the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You say that what he did is merely surpluses that on the --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No question about it because he found violation of paragraph A as well as paragraph D
And with the limited time left, may I discuss --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Could I just ask you --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- before you go on this -- under the New York practice and under a suspended sentence may the defendant be called back into Court and sentenced later is that the end of the matter?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: If it's a straight suspended sentence it's over.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Its over.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The sentence is finished.
Yes sir.
If provisions and limitations are set forth as under the suspended sentence --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But when he doesn't impose the sentence and then suspended it?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That's correct sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But just suspend any sentencing, the case is over?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So there is such a thing then as a final judgment suspending sentence.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I say and that's what we have here?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Well, does that have any consequence at all?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I don't see where it has.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: I mean, it's just like a sort of reprimand, is that what you're telling us?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No.
I'm telling you that this was the punishment meted out by the Court.
They found it in his wisdom to give the defendant a straight suspended sentence.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: And what's a straight suspended sentence?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Just that sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Does that mean that he can -- ever be put in jail for this offense?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Could he ever be fined for this?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No, no sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: So it's sort of a reprimand, is it?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, it's --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, why is he does -- a year or so ago, we've dismissed a couple of case is here wherein a New York prosecution where the man had been fined but he had paid his fine.
We dismissed the case as moot.
Wouldn't this be moved a fortiori under that?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I -- my distinguished colleague has called for a determination of the constitutionality of the statute --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know but that doesn't require us to give it as the case is moot.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I understand.
Whether the question is moot, I certainly submit is for this Court to decide.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What do you think?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, I think we've come a long way for --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You like it -- everyone who comes here wants us to pass on some constitutional question, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I will say this --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Whether do we have to or not?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: May I say this and in due respect; suspended sentence or no, this is a conviction of a misdemeanor of a crime on this man's record.
And if by a judgment of this Court, it is erased I think it is the -- his benefit.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, but if -- then you're suggesting we are wrong a couple of terms ago when we dismissed this misdemeanor convictions where the fine had been paid.
And there were no civil disabilities or anything else (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Perhaps, Mr. Justice White this may be characterized as a more serious offense since it involves possibly moral turpitude and --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what they were.
They were --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well, I don't know the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- obscenity convictions.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Pardon?
They were obscenity --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They were obscenity convictions and a fine had been paid and we dismissed the cases as moot.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Well certainly let me say this from myself.
If I had a misdemeanor conviction upon my record and I had the opportunity to have it erased, I would seek every available pathway toward that end.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That doesn't answer whether or not those other cases are not precedents for dismissing this is moot.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: I can't talk without seeing the cases themselves Mr. Justice Brennan.
I asked you to forgive me because I just don't know the cases into which --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There would be a different proposition I suppose if this suspended -- if these sentences could be imposed.
But if this --

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: There is no sentence --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The case is over.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: -- to be imposed Mr. Justice White.
The case insofar as punishment is concerned is completely over it.
And may I conclude by restating that it is perhaps impossible to determine or measure cause in the realm of social affairs.

It is especially difficult to determine with certainty whether exposure to certain types of influences gradually shapes character or morals in given ways since such shaping force such -- since such shaping force works unobtrusively and does not manifest itself on dramatic incidents of cause and effect.
Thus, persons who demand certain scientific proof maybe asking the impossible.

Constitutional adjudication must be content with a lower order of demonstration or the community will be rendered helpless to protect itself against influences which common knowledge and much expert opinion brands is dangerous.
It should not be made to run the risk or to give itself to give itself to the uncertain rhythms of scientific progress.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The greatest social thinker of our time Robert (Inaudible) has observed that knowledge in the social sciences will always be incomplete and imperfect.
I submit that the danger of these magazines insofar as juveniles are concerned has clearly been established and should be banned.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: In this record?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Has been established in this record?

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: The danger itself sir?

turn.speaker: abe_fortas
turn.label: Justice Abe Fortas
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_cahn
turn.label: Mr. William Cahn
turn.text: No sir, in the cases that have gone here before.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Redfield.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: The few minutes, as to the question of mootness Your Honors on the very day that you dismissed those other cases, one was the Tannenbaum case and the -- I forgot the name of the other one.
This case was granted review and the year had not passed under New York law in which there could be execution under that sentence.
So, well I'm not prepared --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: -- to argue that case now.
That --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I gathered from the state's presentation that once that sentence was suspended, that was the end of the case --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Oh, no, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then, that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Oh, no.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then that -- that no sentence could --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No sentence could be imposed.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: No, I wouldn't go along with that because it's a very same statute you had in the Tannenbaum case and in the other case --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, yes, but there they've --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: -- within the year.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- been (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If they could fine in Tannenbaum.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, but --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They were only fine in those cases.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes, yes, right.
But that wasn't the gist of the decision.
The gist was that there could still have been execution within the year's time and while it may -- perhaps at this moment, I don't know.
I have to study the point.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: While at this moment, the year might have passed that the time you granted review certainly at the time when this case was lodged in this Court though the year have not passed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, Mr. Redfield, I understand that counsel for the state to say that if he merely says suspended sentence without any particular sentence to be suspended but the case has ended then and there --(Voice Overlap) and do you say the opposite (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: I wouldn't accept that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright, now could you both give us a brief memoranda --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- memorandum of the thing in the next day, two or three days.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: You really have it in the other cases because the law set forth (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I know but if it --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- simple, would you --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: I'll be happy to.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: So you'd give us a memorandum.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Please, both (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you say it now why you think it doesn't end?
What else should be done to it?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: What else is to be done?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What else could be done?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, at this moment, I'm not prepared to say that Your Honor because this is the point I haven't even examined.
All I know is this man has this conviction against him and under New York law a second conviction would result in more serious punishment to him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's a different thing.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.
But aside --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, would you cover that, are you sure -- well, I -- I'd be interested with --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Oh, yes, I'm (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- whatever you're going to submit --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: You have it (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, I'm interested in whatever you're going to submit, what the consequences of this maybe.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: If it's a conviction for the purposes of an enhanced punishment on a second conviction that at least to me would be quite important.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.
You have that in the other case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, will you cover it into your memorandum?
Mr. Cahn is shaking his hand -- head vigorously that that isn't so?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, if you look at the record, let's say in the Mishkin case for example, you had that situation where a second conviction led to a higher sentence -- Mishkin have been convicted once before the case, he was in here before and (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Was he here on a misdemeanor?

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: He was (Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: And he got three years -- pardon?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It may be different if a judge uses it in connection with sentences, with sentencing.
That may be different from the law requiring a higher sentence --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, the law --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- because of the prior convictions.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: You mean, whether it's compulsory or whether it's discretionary to judge, is that what you mean?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Well, --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, whatever your state law is, I'm at least would be interested (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: emanuel_redfield
turn.label: Mr. Emanuel Redfield
turn.text: Yes.
I'll be happy to present that but before I terminate, I'd like to point out something that is substantive interest and that is the reliance here upon Mishkin.
I don't think this case has been disposed of by Mishkin.
First of all, in Mishkin you had a deviate class and it was not one of age.
In Mishkin, you have the books, the Court found that the books were directed toward this group and there were prurient appeal to that particular group.

He have an entirely different question of age, and Your Honor was very careful to point out to avoid Hicklin being revived by saying the following, “Since our holding requires that the recipient group be defined with more specificity than in terms of sexually immature persons, it also avoid the inadequacy of the most susceptible person facet of the Hicklin Rule”.
Thank you.
